Award.AwardTitle: Transforming Developmental Mathematics Education in Partnership with Teacher Preparation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transforming Developmental Mathematics Education in Partnership with Teacher Preparation targets students in developmental mathematics courses (DMCs) while strengthening preparation of prospective secondary mathematics teachers (PSMTs). Almost 40% of U.S. undergraduates take at least one DMC (Attewell et al., 2006). Increasingly, technologies like adaptive web-based tutoring systems are used to teach DMCs. Research shows, however, that methods supporting student collaboration are essential for student success in DMCs (Hodera, 2011). This project implements and evaluates a hybrid structure where PSMTs teach DMCs, testing the hypothesis that students enrolled in DMCs, taught using research-based materials and methods, perform better on measures of mathematical proficiency than students not in such classes.

A core feature is that PSMTs, mentored by experienced mathematics educators and using research-based materials and methods, assume responsibility for teaching sections of a DMC. Measures to assess the efficacy of this model include: pre-and post-assessments of students' mathematical proficiency; surveys and interviews soliciting students' interest and self-efficacy in mathematics; video records of PSMTs' instruction, self-reflections about their teaching, and interviews about learning to teach through this experience.

The intellectual merits of this project are two-fold: 1) contribution to the scant literature on hybrid structures that maximize the potential of web-based, adaptive tutoring with face-to-face instruction in DMCs; and 2) development of materials for DMCs that provide guidance to instructors for implementing the instructional model. As a result of disseminating these materials, broader impacts include improved outcomes for under-represented groups, increased STEM participation, and contributions to a teaching force better prepared to teach students who have struggled in mathematics.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Transforming Developmental Mathematics in Partnership with Teacher Preparation Project created and tested a model for supporting the preparation of secondary mathematics teachers that, at the same time, provides a learning experience for developmental mathematics students to better prepare them for undergraduate level mathematics. Undergraduate developmental mathematics is typically an intermediate algebra course offered as a non-credit course for students who place below college algebra upon admission to a post-secondary institution. At the project's participating institution, the developmental mathematics course was offered in both online only and hybrid (face-to-face meetings twice per week) formats, utilizing the ALEKS online curriculum program (Assessment and Learning in Knowledge Spaces; www.aleks.com).

Our model, the University Teaching Experience (UTE) model, engaged undergraduate secondary mathematics teacher candidates in teaching lessons in one of the hybrid sections of the developmental mathematics course. The project designed a curriculum to supplement students' ALEKS assignments through collaborations between university mathematics education researchers and mathematicians that was problem-centered, encouraged collaborative groupwork, and incorporated rich technology applications. The secondary mathematics teacher candidates designed and taught lessons from the curriculum, receiving support and feedback during both the lesson planning and teaching phases of the UTE by university mathematics education researchers who were also instructors for their teaching methods coursework.

To assess the viability of the model and its effectiveness, the project had two primary goals: (1) determine the effects of the UTE model on developmental mathematics students' learning outcomes, which included exam scores during the course and grades in the subsequent credit-bearing mathematics course; and (2) determine the effects of the UTE on secondary mathematics teacher candidates’ abilities to teach in ways that foster mathematical proficiency. To address the first goal, the project collected data from course exams, developed by the mathematics department, taken by the developmental mathematics students during each semester of the project (Fall 2013, Fall 2014). We also collected pre-course assessment measures, in the form of the mathematics department placement test scores and scores from the ALEKS pre-test. In each semester, there were approximately 15-20 students who enrolled in our project's section of the developmental mathematics course. We compared the results of our section's exam scores to students in other sections of the course.

Statistical tests of significance (using the Kruskal test, a non-parametric analog to a MANOVA, which allows multiple comparisons at once) showed that students in our project section, across both semesters, had lower scores on the ALEKS pre-test measures however performed as well as, and in some cases better than, students in the other sections of the developmental mathematics course (both online only and hybrid formats). In addition, students in our project section tended to spend more time on the ALEKS system and had reduced instances of withdrawing enrollment or failing the developmental mathematics course than other sections. 

The second goal of the project was to assess how the UTE supported secondary mathematics teacher candidates in developing skills to teach for mathematical proficiency. We specifically sought to see how the UTE supported their motivation to learn to teach, and the development of their skills to support students' reasoning and sense making. To measure these outcomes, we collected data in the form of videotaped observations of prospective teachers' teaching in the developmental mathematics course, drafts of their lesson plans for these videotaped sessions, interviews with a sample of prospective teachers, and prospective teachers' written reflections on their teaching in the developmental mathematics course.

To date, there are two significant findings from the analysis of the data on opportunities for prospective teachers to learn to teach in the UTE. First, there is clear evidence from analysis of their responses to interview questions about the UTE experience that they specifically name the experience as an opportunity to develop skills in leading whole-class discussions about mathematics that other field placements, including school-based placements, had not offered in their teacher preparation program thus far. The second finding, coming from interview data and the written reflections on their teaching, shows that prospective teachers recognize the importance of learning to teach well from the UTE because they do not want their future students to have to enroll in a non-credit mathematics course when they begin post-secondary education. The opportunity to work with students in the developmental class offers a chance to see students who likely have not been well-served by their K-12 schooling, and the prospective teachers gain awareness of differential opportunities to learn that students can have in K-12 education and motivation to become effective secondary mathematics teachers.

As a result of this project, we have designed an inquiry-oriented curriculum for use in a hybrid developmental mathematics course and refined the UTE model as an early field experience for prospective secondary mathematics teachers. The next phase of the project is to scale the UTE model to other teacher preparation programs.
